articles.title: Claudette Colvin, US civil rights pioneer, dies at 86
articles.summary: Colvin was arrested for refusing to give up her bus seat to a white person months before the famous case of Rosa Parks.
articles.content:
Claudette Colvin, US civil rights pioneer, dies at 86

Colvin's arrest was largely unknown until 2009, when the first detailed book about her experience was published.

It happened nine months before the arrest of Rosa Parks, who also famously refused to give her bus seat to a white person, in a move that led to widespread boycotting of public transportation in the city, and a Supreme Court decision that outlawed such racial discrimination.

Colvin's protest, which led to her arrest, came in 1955 at the age of 15 while she was living in Montgomery, Alabama.

Claudette Colvin, who helped end racial segregation in the US by refusing to give up her bus seat to a white person, has died. She was 86 years old.

"She leaves behind a legacy of courage that helped change the course of American history," said a statement from the Claudette Colvin Legacy Foundation, which announced her death.

One year after her arrest, the US Supreme Court ruled that segregation on buses must end. The legal case turned on the testimony of four plaintiffs, one of whom was Colvin.

In an interview with the BBC in 2018, Ms Colvin recalled that she "was not frightened, but disappointed and angry" because she knew she "was sitting in the right seat".

She was the first person to be arrested for challenging Montgomery's bus segregation policies, but her story remained relatively unknown for decades. It was Rosa Parks who became one of the main figures of the civil rights movement after her very similar case led to the large-scale boycott of the bus system in the city.

Colvin said she had been inspired by the great anti-slavery campaigners Harriet Tubman and Sojourner Truth.

"Whenever people ask me: 'Why didn't you get up when the bus driver asked you?' I say it felt as though Harriet Tubman's hands were pushing me down on one shoulder and Sojourner Truth's hands were pushing me down on the other shoulder," she told the BBC.

Later in life, she became a nurse in New York. According to her organisation, she died in Texas.

articles.personality_title: Claudette Colvin, civil rights pioneer, remembered for her early stand against bus segregation
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 1955 Montgomery, Alabama, buses were segregated by race, meaning Black people had to give up their seats to white passengers. This was a common rule but deeply unfair.

**What happened** – Claudette Colvin, a 15-year-old Black girl, refused to give up her seat to a white person on a bus. She was arrested for this act of protest, which happened nine months before Rosa Parks’ similar and more famous protest. Colvin’s story was mostly unknown until a book about her came out in 2009.

**Impact** – Claudette Colvin’s brave action helped challenge the unfair bus segregation laws. She was one of the people who gave testimony in a court case that led the US Supreme Court to end bus segregation a year later. Her courage contributed to a major change in American history, even if she did not receive much recognition at the time.

**What’s next step** – Colvin’s story is now shared more widely, helping people learn about the many individuals who fought for civil rights. This encourages a fuller understanding of history and inspires new generations to stand up against injustice.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Claudette Colvin’s early refusal to give up her bus seat played a key role in ending racial segregation on public transportation in the United States.
articles.personality_title_fr: Claudette Colvin, pionnière des droits civiques, reconnue pour son premier acte contre la ségrégation dans les bus
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 1955 à Montgomery, en Alabama, les bus étaient séparés selon la race, ce qui obligeait les personnes noires à céder leur place aux passagers blancs. Cette règle, bien que courante, était profondément injuste.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Claudette Colvin, une jeune fille noire de 15 ans, a refusé de céder sa place à une personne blanche dans un bus. Elle a été arrêtée pour cet acte de protestation, neuf mois avant un geste similaire et plus connu de Rosa Parks. L’histoire de Colvin est restée peu connue jusqu’à la publication d’un livre en 2009.

**Impact** – Le courage de Claudette Colvin a aidé à remettre en question les lois injustes sur la ségrégation dans les bus. Elle a été l’une des personnes à témoigner lors d’un procès qui a conduit la Cour Suprême des États-Unis à mettre fin à cette ségrégation un an plus tard. Son action a contribué à un changement majeur dans l’histoire américaine, même si elle n’a pas été reconnue à l’époque.

**Prochaine étape** – L’histoire de Colvin est maintenant mieux partagée, permettant à chacun de découvrir les nombreuses personnes qui ont combattu pour les droits civiques. Cela encourage une meilleure compréhension de l’histoire et inspire les nouvelles générations à lutter contre l’injustice.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le refus précoce de Claudette Colvin de céder sa place dans un bus a joué un rôle clé dans la fin de la ségrégation raciale dans les transports publics aux États-Unis.
articles.personality_title_es: Claudette Colvin, pionera de los derechos civiles, recordada por su primera protesta contra la segregación en autobuses
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 1955 en Montgomery, Alabama, los autobuses estaban segregados por raza, lo que obligaba a las personas negras a ceder su asiento a los pasajeros blancos. Esta regla era común pero injusta.

**Qué pasó** – Claudette Colvin, una niña negra de 15 años, se negó a ceder su asiento a una persona blanca en un autobús. Fue arrestada por esta protesta, que ocurrió nueve meses antes de un acto similar y más conocido de Rosa Parks. La historia de Colvin fue poco conocida hasta que en 2009 se publicó un libro sobre ella.

**Impacto** – La valiente acción de Claudette Colvin ayudó a desafiar las leyes injustas de segregación en los autobuses. Fue una de las personas que testificaron en un juicio que llevó a la Corte Suprema de Estados Unidos a terminar con la segregación en los autobuses un año después. Su coraje contribuyó a un cambio importante en la historia estadounidense, aunque no recibió mucho reconocimiento en ese momento.

**Próximo paso** – Ahora se comparte más la historia de Colvin, ayudando a que más personas conozcan a quienes lucharon por los derechos civiles. Esto fomenta una comprensión más completa de la historia e inspira a nuevas generaciones a defender la justicia.

**Resumen en una frase** – La temprana negativa de Claudette Colvin a ceder su asiento en un autobús fue clave para acabar con la segregación racial en el transporte público de Estados Unidos.
